./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Reaction
Reaction is a library for asynchronous and reactive programming, and is an implementation of Async Observables (ReactiveX) for F# and Fable. Reaction makes it easy to compose and combine streams of asynchronous event based data such as timers, mouse-moves, keyboard input, web requests and enables you to do operations such as:

Filter
Transform
Aggregate
Combine
Time-shift

Reaction was designed spesifically for targeting Fable which means that the code may be transpiled to JavaScript, and thus the same F# code may be used both client and server side for full stack software development.
See Fable Reaction for use of Reaction with Elmish and the model view update (MVU) style architecture.

pages/Install.html.title: Installing
pages/Install.html.body:
Install
Reaction is available as a NuGet package for NETStandard 2.0.
> paket add Reaction --project 

There is a dependency for FSharp.Control.AsyncSeq, but only when used with .NET (not Fable).

pages/GettingStarted.html.title: Getting Started

pages/Types.html.title: Core Types and Interfaces
pages/Types.html.body:
Types
Reaction is built around the interfaces IAsyncDisposable, IAsyncObserver and IAsyncObservable. This enables a familiar Rx programming syntax similar to FSharp.Control.Reactive with the difference that all methods are Async.
type IAsyncDisposable =
    abstract member DisposeAsync: unit -> Async

type IAsyncObserver =
    abstract member OnNextAsync: 'a -> Async
    abstract member OnErrorAsync: exn -> Async
    abstract member OnCompletedAsync: unit -> Async

type IAsyncObservable =
    abstract member SubscribeAsync: IAsyncObserver -> Async

The relationship between these three interfaces can be seen in this single line of code. You get an async disposable by subscribing asynchronously to an async observable with an async observer:
async {
    let! disposableAsync = observable.SubscribeAsync observerAsync
    ...
}

Notifications
Observers may written as a function accepting Notification which is defined as the following discriminated union:
type Notification =
    | OnNext of 'a
    | OnError of exn
    | OnCompleted

You can read more about observers in the Observers section.

pages/Observers.html.title: Observers

pages/Observables.html.title: Observables
pages/Observables.html.body:
Async Observables
Reaction is an implementation of Async Observable. The difference between an "Async Observable" and an "Observable" is that with "Async Observables" you need to await methods such as Subscribe, OnNext, OnError, and OnCompleted. In Reaction they are thus called SubscribeAsync, OnNextAsync, OnErrorAsync, and OnCompletedAsync. This enables SubscribeAsync to await async operations i.e setup network connections, and observers (OnNext) may finally await side effects such as writing to disk (observers are all about side-effects right?).
This diagram shows the how Async Observables relates to other collections and values.




Single Value
Multiple Values




Synchronous pull
unit -> 'a
seq


Synchronous push
'a -> unit
Observable


Asynchronous pull
unit -> Async
AsyncSeq


Asynchronous push
'a -> Async
AsyncObservable

pages/Disposables.html.title: Disposables
pages/Disposables.html.body:
Disposables
Asynchronous disposables are similar to IDisposable but with the difference that it encapsulates an async dispose method called DisposeAsync.
type AsyncDisposable (cancel) =
    interface IAsyncDisposable with
        member this.DisposeAsync () =
            async {
                do! cancel ()
            }

In additon the following static members have been defined:

Create : (unit -> Async) -> IAsyncDisposable, creates an IAsyncDisposable from an async cancel function. Same instantiating the object, but the return value here is anonymous.
Empty : unit -> IAsyncDisposable, creates an empty disposable that will do nothing if it's disposed.
Composite : seq -> IAsyncDisposable, creates a disposable from a sequence of disposables. If disposed then all the contained disposables will also be disposed.

The SubscribeAsync method for async observables returns an async disposable, and to cancel the subscription you need to call the DisposeAsync method.
let xs = ofSeq ()
let! subscription = xs.SubscribeAsync obv

// Unsubscribe
do! subscription.DisposeAsync ()

pages/Streams.html.title: Streams
pages/Streams.html.body:
Streams
You can think of a "Stream" as being a tube that is open at both sides. Streams combines both the IAsyncObservable and IAsyncObserver interfaces. Whatever you put in (e.g OnNextAsync) at one side (IAsyncObserver) will come out of the other end (IAsyncObservable).
Streams and are similar to the classic Subject in ReactiveX. The difference is that a Stream in Reaction is not a single object, but a tuple of two entangled objects where one implements IAsyncObserver, and the other implements IAsyncObservable. This solves the problem of having a single object trying to be two things at once (what is the dual of an ISubject anyways?).
There are currently 3 types of streams in Reaction:

stream, unit -> IAsyncObserver * IAsyncObservable
mbStream, unit -> MailboxProcessor> * IAsyncObservable
singleStream, unit -> IAsyncObserver * IAsyncObservable

Stream
The stream will forward any notification pushed to the IAsyncObserver side to all observers that have subscribed to the IAsyncObservable side. The stream is hot in the sense that if there are no observers, then the notification will be lost.

stream : unit -> IAsyncObserver * IAsyncObservable

let dispatch, obs = stream ()

let main = async {
    let! sub = obs.SubscribeAsync obv
    do! dispatch.OnNextAsync 42
    ...
}

Async.StartImmediate main ()

Mailbox Stream
Same as a stream except that the observer is exposed as a MailboxProcessor>. The mailbox stream is hot in the sense that if there are no observers, then any pushed notification will be lost.

mbStream : unit -> MailboxProcessor> * IAsyncObservable

let dispatch, obs = mbStream ()

let main = async {
    let! sub = obs.SubscribeAsync obv
    do dispatch.Post (OnNext 42)
    ...
}

Async.StartImmediate main ()

Single Stream
The stream will forward any notification pushed to the IAsyncObserver side to a single observer that have subscribed to the IAsyncObservable side. The single stream is "cold" in the sense that if there's no-one observing, then the writer will be awaited until there is a subscriber that can observe the value being pushed. You can use a single stream in scenarios that requires so called backpressure.

singleStream : unit -> IAsyncObserver * IAsyncObservable

let dispatch, obs = singleStream ()

let main = async {
    let! sub = obs.SubscribeAsync obv
    do! dispatch.OnNextAsync 42
    ...
}

Async.StartImmediate main ()

pages/Operators.html.title: Operators
pages/Operators.html.body:
Operators
The following parameterized async observerable returning functions (operators) are
currently supported. Other operators may be implemented on-demand, but the goal is to keep it simple and not make this into a full featured ReactiveX implementation (if possible).
To use the operators open either the Reaction namespace.
open Reaction

xs = AsyncObserable.single 42

You can also open the Reaction.AsyncObserable module if you don't want to prepend every operator with AsyncObservable. Be aware of possible namespace conflicts with operators such as map.
open Reaction.AsyncObserable

xs = single 42

For the examples below we assume that Reaction.AsyncObservale is opened.
Creating
Functions for creating ('a -> IAsyncObservable) an async observable.
empty
Returns an async observable sequence with no elements. You must usually indicate which type the resulting observable should be since empty itself doesn't produce any values.
val empty : unit : IAsyncObservable

Example:
let xs = empty ()

single
Returns an observable sequence containing the single specified
element.
val single : x: 'a -> IAsyncObservable =

Example:
let xs = single 42

fail
Returns the observable sequence that terminates exceptionally
with the specified exception.
val fail error: exn -> IAsyncObservable =

Example:
exception MyError of string

let error = MyError "error"
let xs = fail error

defer
Returns an observable sequence that invokes the specified factory
function whenever a new observer subscribes.
val defer : factory: (unit -> IAsyncObservable) -> IAsyncObservable

create
Creates an async observable (AsyncObservable) from the
given subscribe function.
val create : subscribe: (IAsyncObserver -> Async) -> IAsyncObservable

Example:
exception MyError of string

let error = MyError "error"
let xs = fail error


ofSeq : seq -> IAsyncObservable, Returns the async observable sequence whose elements are pulled
  from the given enumerable sequence.
ofAsyncSeq : AsyncSeq -> IAsyncObservable, Convert async sequence into an async observable (Not available in Fable).
timer : int -> IAsyncObservable, Returns an observable sequence that triggers the value 0
  after the given duetime.
interval int -> IAsyncObservable, Returns an observable sequence that triggers the increasing
  sequence starting with 0 after the given period.

Transforming
Functions for transforming (IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable) an async observable.
map
Returns an observable sequence whose elements are the result of
invoking the mapper function on each element of the source.
val map : mapper: ('a -> 'b) -> source: IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Example:
let mapper x = x * 10

let xs = single 42 |> map mapper


mapi : ('a*int -> 'b) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
mapAsync : ('a -> Async) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
mapiAsync : ('a*int -> Async) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMap : ('a -> IAsyncObservable) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMapi : ('a*int -> IAsyncObservable) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMapAsync : ('a -> Async\\>) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMapiAsync : ('a*int -> Async\>) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMapLatest : ('a -> IAsyncObservable) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
flatMapLatestAsync : ('a -> Async\>) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
catch : (exn -> IAsyncObservable) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Filtering
Functions for filtering (IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable) an async observable.
filter
Filters the elements of an observable sequence based on a
predicate. Returns an observable sequence that contains elements
from the input sequence that satisfy the condition.
val filter : predicate: ('a -> bool) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Example:
let predicate x = x  filter predicate


filterAsync : ('a -> Async\) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
distinctUntilChanged : IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
takeUntil : IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
choose : ('a -> 'b option) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
chooseAsync : ('a -> Async) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Aggregating
scan
Applies an accumulator function over an observable sequence for every value 'a and returns each intermediate result 's. The initial seed value is used as the initial accumulator value. Returns an observable sequence containing the accumulated values 's.
val scan : initial: 's -> accumulator: ('s -> 'a -> 's) -> source: IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Example:
let scanner a x = a + x

let xs = ofSeq  scan 0 scanner

scanAsync
Applies an async accumulator function over an observable
sequence and returns each intermediate result. The seed value is
used as the initial accumulator value. Returns an observable
sequence containing the accumulated values.
val scan : initial: 's -> accumulator: ('s -> 'a -> Async) -> source: IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Example:
let scannerAsync a x = async { return a + x }

let xs = ofSeq  scanAsync 0 scannerAsync

groupBy
Groups the elements of an observable sequence according to a
specified key mapper function. Returns a sequence of observable
groups, each of which corresponds to a given key.
val groupBy : keyMapper: ('a -> 'g) -> source: IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable>

Example:
let xs = ofSeq [1; 2; 3; 4; 5; 6]
        |> groupBy (fun x -> x % 2)
        |> flatMap (fun x -> x)

Combining
Functions for combining multiple async observables into one.

merge : IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
mergeInner : IAsyncObservable\\> -> IAsyncObservable
switchLatest : IAsyncObservable> -> IAsyncObservable
concat : seq> -> IAsyncObservable
startWith : seq -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
combineLatest : IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
withLatestFrom : IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
zipSeq : seq -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Time-shifting
Functions for time-shifting (IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable) an async observable.

delay : int -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
debounce : int -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

sample
Samples the observable sequence at each interval.
val sample : msecs: int source: IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable

Leaving
Functions for leaving (IAsyncObservable -> 'a) the async observable.

toAsyncSeq : IAsyncObservable -> AsyncSeq (Not available in Fable)

pages/Query.html.title: Query Builder
pages/Query.html.body:
Query Builder
Queries may be written by composing functions or using query expressions.
let xs = reaction {
    yield 42
}

This expression is equivalent to:
let xs = AsyncObservable.single 42

You can also yield multiple values:
let xs = reaction {
    yield 42
    yield 43
}

This is equivalent to:
let xs = AsyncObservable.ofSeq [42; 43]

// or

let xs = AsyncObservable.concat [AsyncObservable.single 42; AsyncObservable.single 43]

Flat mapping
let xs = reaction {
    let! i = single 42
    yield i*10
}

This is equivalent to:
let xs =
    AsyncObservable.single 42
    |> flatMap (fun i ->
        AsynbObservable.single (i * 10))
}

More advanced example
These two examples below are equivalent:
Seq.toList "TIME FLIES LIKE AN ARROW"
|> Seq.mapi (fun i c -> i, c)
|> ofSeq
|> flatMap (fun (i, c) ->
    fromMouseMoves ()
    |> delay (100 * i)
    |> map (fun m -> Letter (i, string c, int m.clientX, int m.clientY)))

The above query may be written in query expression style:
reaction {
    let! i, c = Seq.toList "TIME FLIES LIKE AN ARROW"
                |> Seq.mapi (fun i c -> i, c)
                |> ofSeq
    let ms = fromMouseMoves () |> delay (100 * i)
    for m in ms do
        yield Letter (i, string c, int m.clientX, int m.clientY)
}

pages/Errors.html.title: Error Handling
pages/Errors.html.body:
Error Handling
Reactive applications also need to handle exceptions. But unlike normal applications where exceptions fly upwards, exceptions in a reactive application goes the other way and propagates down the chain of operators.
Observables will dispose the subscription if any errors occur. No event can be observed after an OnError. This may sound like a restriction, but if we think of the dual world of iterables, then we know that if the iterator throws an exception, then the iteration is over. Observables works in just the same but opposite way.
When dealing with errors there are several strategies to choose:

Retrying subscriptions
Catching exceptions
Ignoring exceptions
Logging errors

It's important to notice that observer implementations should never throw exceptions. This is because we expect that (1) the observer implementor knows best how to handle those exceptions and we can't do anything reasonable with them, and (2) if an exception occurs then we want that to bubble out of and not into the reactive framework.
The following error handling operators have been implemented:

catch : (exn -> IAsyncObservable) -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable,

pages/Custom.html.title: Custom Observables

extras/Giraffe.html.title: Giraffe Middleware
extras/Giraffe.html.body:
Reaction Middleware for Giraffe
The Reaction Middleware for Giraffe is an experimental support for server side WebSocket message handling.
Install
> paket add Reaction.Giraffe --project 

Getting Started
You add the Reaction middleware to Giraffe using the UseReaction method on the IApplicationBuilder in the configureApp function of the Giraffe setup.
let query (connectionId: ConnectionId) (msgs: IAsyncObservable) : IAsyncObservable =
    msgs
    |> filter (fun (msg, cId) -> cId = connectionId)

let configureApp (app : IApplicationBuilder) =
    app.UseWebSockets()
       .UseReaction(fun options ->
       { options with
           Query = query
           Encode = Msg.Encode
           Decode = Msg.Decode
       })
       .UseDefaultFiles()
       .UseStaticFiles()
       .UseGiraffe webApp

Options
Options may be overrided by UseReaction.
[]
type ReactionConfig =
    {
        QueryAll: IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
        Query: ConnectionId -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable
        Encode: 'msg -> string
        Decode: string -> 'msg option
        RequestPath: string
    }

Query
A query for the stream of messages to a given client. The type of the query is ConnectionId -> IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable.
The query function takes a connectionId and an AsyncObservable. The connectionId is the id for a particular clients connection. Messages that leaves in the returned observable will only go to that particular client. Notifications will be a tuple 'msg*ConnectionId where 'msg is the message being handled and the connectionId is the client connection where this message was received.
Thus this query will only send messages back to the same client that sent them. Messages for other clients will be filtered.
let query (connectionId: ConnectionId) (msgs: IAsyncObservable) : IAsyncObservable =
    msgs
    |> filter (fun (msg, cId) -> cId = connectionId)

This query will only send back messages from other clients. Messages that the client sent itself will be filtered.
let query (connectionId: ConnectionId) (msgs: IAsyncObservable) : IAsyncObservable =
    msgs
    |> filter (fun (msg, cId) -> cId <> connectionId)

QueryAll
This query is of type IAsyncObservable -> IAsyncObservable and is a query for the single stream of all messages to and from all clients. This query is processed first, and enables us to send messages that needs to be received by all clients. Thus we may produce messages out of thin air (timers etc) and send them to all connected clients.
Encode
Encoder for serializing a message to JSON string. The type of encoder is 'msg -> string.
Decode
Decoder for deserializing a JSON string to a message. The type of decoder is string -> 'msg option.
RequestPath
Request path where the server will liste for websocket requests. Default is /ws. You will usually not need to change this.
